Award.AwardTitle: Computational methods for materials science, high frequency wave propagation, and quantum mechanics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project involves modeling, simulation, and efficient computation of technologically important and intellectually interesting problems. In the area of material science the research investigates two new off-lattice methods for the computational modeling of the evolution of crystalline materials in which the lattice structure may change. This is needed when defect formation is important, for example. The project will also address the efficient computation of high frequency wave propagation in nonhomogeneous materials. This classic problem in computational science and applied mathematics has attracted much attention because it is useful for problems in geophysics and optics and it is a mathematically rich problem requiring insight into the behavior of wave equation. The PI also plans to develop numerical methods for studying quantum dynamics of molecules. The importance of quantum mechanics in understanding chemical reactions cannot be overstated, and this research offers the potential of providing detailed insight and predictive power for a variety of photo-induced chemical reactions. The project also involves training of graduate students.

The first project involves developement of off-lattice computation models for the evolution of crystalline materials. In one case, the PI plans to formulate an off-lattice kinetic Monte Carlo method for the simulation of epitaxial growth and in other an alternative to the phase field crystal method is proposed. In both cases the underlying energy of the system is a suitable intermolecular potential. In addition, in both cases one will be computing on time scales orders of magnitude larger than molecular dynamics. Another project involves the computation of high frequency solutions of the wave equation. The goal is to exploit the asymptotic structure of high frequency solutions to develop efficient numerical methods that do not have the errors that result from asymptotic approximations that occur when one uses methods that rely on geometrical optics or Gaussian beams. The PI also plans to develop numerical methods for the studying quantum dynamics of molecules when conical intersections play an important role. A full quantum mechanical treatment would mean solving the Schroedinger equation in 20 to 30 dimensions even for small molecules. Our plan is to identify the important modes by using surface hopping methods as a probe of the energy landscape. A full quantum treatment can then be accurately obtained just using this smaller set of modes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed computational tools for a number of mathematical problems that stem from applications in materials science and engineering 

 

 One outcome of the project concerns the Schroedinger equation in the semiclassical limit.  Fast solution of the semiclassical limit of the Schroedinger equation has many important applications, such as simulation of chemical reaction dynamics.  In this limit, solutions become highly oscillatory and difficult to compute. The challenge is to compute accurate solutions without needing to resolve the high frequency oscillations. This has been done by a clever transformation of the equation, which ?extracts? much of the oscillatory nature of the solution and leaves an equation that is more amenable to efficient computation.  In a work done as part of previous NSF support, an algorithm was developed for the Schreodinger equation with scalar potential and constant refraction index. Under the present project, the technique has been extended to more general contexts: (i) to the Schoedinger equation with vector potential, which describes, for example, a quantum particle in an electromagnetic field; (ii) to uncertainty quantification of quantum systems in the semiclassical limit, when uncertainties are present in the initial condition or in the potential and (iii) to study the propagation of high frequency waves in media with a slowly varying refraction index. Geometrical optics describes light propagation as rays, neglecting diffraction. Our technique is able to efficiently captures small but non negligible deviation from geometrical optics, without resolving the small scales associated with the wavelength, which in many cases is prohibitively expensive. 

 

 Another outcome of this project relates to the study of Graphene, a single atom thick, two dimensional structure formed by carbon atoms when they arrange themselves in a honeycomb pattern. It holds great promise in technological applications due to its unique properties. To simulate the formation and behavior of graphene on the computer, materials scientists have developed mathematical models at various levels of complexity and detail. Part of the project investigated theoretically which details of these models are responsible for capturing the essential features of the graphene structure. For instance, is it necessary to prescribe in the model that carbon atoms prefer 120 degree bond angles, as found in the honeycomb pattern? The study found that the answer is no in the plane: the honeycomb pattern can still emerge even if the carbon atoms prefer 180 degree bond angles. It is hoped that these insights will be helpful in guiding the future efforts of scientists in more detailed and accurate modeling of graphene.

 

 Another outcome examines the role of locality in molecular orbitals and vibrations, and questioned the assumptions behind common methods used in quantum chemistry. We found that a continuum of possibilities was present between the fully localized and fully delocalized limits, and constructed tools for mapping one side of these possibilities to the other. By finding optimal degrees of locality between the limits, improved vibrational wave functions could be formed at much reduced costs. 

 Finally, we have provided insight into the inner workings of machine learning tools for problems with chemical reactions. We have examined support vector machines (SVM) and neural networks (NN), and showed high predictive value in cross-validated test sets, when trained on quantum chemical reaction data. We created maps that transfer information from one feature set to another (e.g. graphical features to atomistic charges), enabling a clear explanation as to why SVMs and NNs alike provide high accuracy when using widely disparate types of features. We found that these tools give statistical accuracy even when chemically relevant features are totally lacking ? this important insight invalidates numerous incorrect explanations being used in the chemistry community for the apparent power of machine learning. Instead, we provide an information-centric explanation for results from machine learning, which is better in line with expectations from data science. 

 

This project provided support for 1 MSc and 3 PhD students
